Preamble

Democracy is a common value shared by all humanity. It is a right for all nations, not aâprerogativeâreserved to aâfew. Democracy takes different forms, and there is no one-size-fits-all model. It would be totally undemocratic to measure the diverse political systems in the world with a single yardstick or examine different political civilizations from a single perspective. The political system of a country should be independently decided by its own people. â

The United Statesâ system of democracyâis derived from its own practices. This system is unique, not universally applicable, and it is far from perfect. However, over the years, the US,âdespite theâstructural flaws and problematic practiceâof its democratic system, has claimed itself asâthe âmodel of democracyâ. It has incessantly interferedâin other countriesâ internal affairs and waged wars under the guise of âdemocracyâ, creating regional turbulence and humanitarian disasters. â

Based on facts and expert opinions, this report aims to expose the deficiencies andâabuse of democracy inâthe USâas well as the harm of its exporting suchâdemocracy. It is hoped that the USâwill improve its own system and practices of democracy and change its way of interacting with other countries. This is in the interest of not only the American people, but also the people of other countries. If no countryâseeks toâdictate standards for democracy, impose its own political system on others or use democracy as a tool to suppress others, and when all countries can live and thrive in diversity, our world will be a better place.

I.âWhat is democracy?

Democracy is a term that derives from the ancient Greek language. It means ârule by the peopleâ or âsovereignty of the peopleâ. As a form of government, democracy has been practiced for over 2,500 years, though in different forms, such as direct democracy of the ancient Athenianâcitizens and representative government in modern times. Democracyâis a manifestation of theâpolitical advancement of humanity.

Democracy is not an adornment or publicity stunt; rather, it is meant to beâused to solve problems faced by the people. To judge whether a country is democratic, it is important to see whether its people run their own country. In addition to voting rights, it is important to see whether people have theârights to extensive participation. It is important to see what promises are made in an electionâcampaignâand, more importantly, how many of those promises are honored afterwards. It is important to see what political procedures and rules are instituted by a countryâs systems and laws and, more importantly, whether these systems and laws are truly executed. It is important to see whether the rules and procedures governing the exercise of power are democratic and, more importantly, whether power is truly put under the oversight and checks of the people.

A functional democracy must have a full set ofâinstitutional procedures; more importantly, it should have full participation of the people. It must ensure democracy in terms of both process and outcomes. It must encompass both procedural and substantive democracy, both direct and indirect democracy.âIt must ensure both peopleâs democracy and the will of the State. If the people of a country are only called upon to vote and then are forgotten once they have cast their votes; if the people only hear high-sounding promises during an election campaign but have no say whatsoever afterwards; or if they are wooed when their votes are wanted but are ignored once the election is over, then such a democracy is not a true democracy.

Whether a country is democratic should be judged and determined by its own people, not by a minority of self-righteous outsiders.

There is no perfect system of democracyâin the world, nor is there a political system that fits all countries. Democracy is established and developed based on a countryâs own history and adapted to its national context, and each countryâs democracy has its unique value. Members of the international community should engage in exchanges and dialogues on democracy on the basis of equality and mutual respect, and work together to contribute to the progress of humanity.

II.âThe alienation and three malaises of democracy in the US

From a historical perspective, the development of democracyâin the USâwasâa step forward. The political party system, the representative system, one person one vote, and the separation of powers negatedâand reformed the feudal autocracy in Europe. The well-known French writerâAlexis de Tocquevilleârecognized this in his bookâDemocracy in America. The Declaration of Independence, the Bill of Rights, abolitionist movement, civil rights movement and affirmative action were highlights in the advancement of American democracy. The principle of âgovernment of the people, by the people and for the peopleââarticulatedâby Abraham Lincoln isârecognized worldwide.

However,âover the years, democracy in the USâhas becomeâalienated and degenerated, and it has increasingly deviated from the essenceâof democracy and its original design. Problems like money politics, identity politics, wrangling between political parties, political polarization, social division, racial tension and wealth gap have become more acute. All this has weakened the functioning of democracy in the US.

The USâhas often used democracy as a pretext to meddleâin other countriesââinternal affairs, causingâpolitical chaos and social unrest in theseâcountries, and underminingâworld peace and stability and social tranquility in other countries. This makes many people in the USâand other countries wonder if the USâis still a democracy.âThe world needs toâtake a closer look atâtheâcurrent state ofâdemocracyâin the US, and the USâitself should also conductâsome soul-searching.

1.âThe system fraught with deep-seated problems

The USâcalls itselfââcity upon a hillââand a âbeacon ofâdemocracyâ; and it claims that its political system was designed to defend democracy and freedom at the time of itsâfounding. Yet, the vision of democracy has lost its shine in the USâtoday. The self-styled American democracy is now gravelyâillâwith moneyâpolitics, elite rule, political polarization and a dysfunctional system.

(1) American-style democracy has become âa game of money politicsâ

The American-style democracy is a rich menâs game based on capital, andâis fundamentally different from democracy of the people.

Over a hundred years ago, Republican Senator from Ohio Mark Hannaâsaid ofâAmerican politics: âThere are two things that are important in politics. The first is money, and I canât remember the second.ââMore than one hundred years have passed, and money has not only remained âthe currencyââin US politics, but also become even more indispensable. For example, the 2020 presidential election and Congressional elections cost some US$14 billion, two times that of 2016 and three times that of 2008;âindeed, they are known as the most expensive elections in American history. The cost of the presidential election reached another record high of US$6.6 billion, and the Congressional elections cost over US$7 billion.

The fact that the American peopleâhave toâface is that moneyâpolitics has penetrated the entireâprocess of election, legislation and administration. People in fact only have a restrictedâright to political participation. The inequality in economic status has been turned into inequality in political status. Only people with enough capital can enjoy theirâdemocratic rights provided by the Constitution. Moneyâpolitics have increasingly become an âirremovable tumorââin American societyâand a mockery ofâdemocracyâin the US.

A US Senator had a sharp observation,ââCongress does not regulate Wall Street. Wall Street regulates Congress.ââAccording to statistics, winners of 91% of US Congressional elections are the candidates with greater financialâsupport. Big companies, a small group of rich people, and interest groups are generous with their support and have become the main source of electoralâfunding. And thoseâso-called representatives of the people, once elected, often serve the interests of their financial backers. They speak for vested interests rather than the ordinary people. â

In March 2020, Robert Reich, Professor of Public Policy at University of California, Berkeley and former Secretary of Labor, published a book entitled The System, Who Rigged It, How We Fix It. According to him, the American political system has been hijacked by a tiny minorityâover the past four decades. Political donations are almost seen as âlegitimate briberyâ. They enable the rich to have more political clout. During the 2018 midterm elections, the huge political donations, mostly coming from the top 0.01% ultra-rich of the American population, accounted for over 40% of campaign finance. Money politics and lobby groups are restricting channels for ordinary Americans to speak out, whose voices expressing genuine concerns are overshadowed by a handful of interest groups. The oligarchs would enrich themselves with the power they have got while totally ignoring the interests of ordinary Americans.

On 23 September 2020, in an interview with Harvard Law Today, Harvard Law School Professor Matthew Stephenson said that the US is by no means the world leader in clean government, and certain practices related to lobbying and campaign finance that other countries would consider corrupt are not only permitted but constitutionally protected in the US.

(2)âââOne person one voteâ in name, ârule of the minority eliteâ in reality

The US is a typical country dominated by an elite class. Political pluralism is only a facade. A small number of elites dominate the political, economic and military affairs. They control the state apparatus and policy-making process, manipulate public opinion, dominate the business community and enjoy all kinds of privileges. Since the 1960s in particular, the Democrats and Republicans have taken turns to exercise power, making the âmultiparty systemâ dead in all but name. For ordinary voters, casting their votes to a third party or an independent candidate is nothing more than wasting the ballot. In effect, they can only choose either the Democratic candidate or the Republican one.

In the context of Democratic-Republican rivalry, the general publicâs participation in politics is restricted to a very narrow scope. For ordinary voters, they are only called upon to vote and are forgotten once they have cast their ballots. Most people are just âwalk-onsâ in the theater of election. This makes âgovernment by the peopleâ hardly possible in US political practice.

Noam Chomsky, a political commentator and social activist from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, points out that the USâis a âreally existing capitalist democracyâ, where there is a positive correlation between peopleâs wealth and their influence on policy-making. For the lower 70% on the wealth/income scale, they have no influence on policy whatsoever. They are effectively disenfranchised.

Ray La Raja, Professor atâthe University of Massachusetts,ânotes in an article forâThe Atlanticâthat Americaâs current system is democratic only in form, not in substance. Theânominating processâis vulnerable to manipulation by plutocrats, celebrities, media figures and activists. Many presidentialâprimary voters mistakenly back candidates who do not reflect their views.

(3) The checks and balances have resulted in a âvetocracyâ

American political scientist Francis Fukuyama points out in his book Political Order and Political Decayâthat there is an entrenched political paralysis in the US. The US political system has far too many checks and balances,âraising the cost of collective action and in some cases making it impossible altogether. Fukuyama calls the system a âvetocracyâ. Since the 1980s, the âvetocracyââof the USâhas become a formula for gridlock.

TheâUS democratic process is fragmented and lengthy, with a lot of veto points where individual veto players can block action by the whole body. The function of âchecks and balancesâ, which was purportedly designed to prevent abuse of power, has beenâdistorted in American political practice. Political polarization continues to growâas the two parties drift further apart inâpolitical agenda andâtheirâareas of consensus have reduced significantly. An extreme case is the fact that âthe most liberal Republican now remains significantly to the right of the most conservative Democratâ. Antagonism and mutual inhibition have become commonplace, âvetocracyââhas defined Americanâpolitical culture, and a vindictive âif I canât, you canât eitherââmentality has grown prevalent.

Politicians in Washington, D.C.âare preoccupied with securing their own partisan interestsâand donât care at all about national development. Vetoing makes one identify more strongly with their peers in the same camp, who mayâin turn giveâthem greaterâand quickerâsupport. Consequently the two parties are caught in a vicious circle, addicted to vetoing. Worse still, theâgovernment efficacy is inevitably weakened, law and justice trampled upon, development and progress stalled, and social division widened. In the US today, people are increasingly identifying themselves as a Republican or a Democrat instead of as an American. The negative impacts of identity politics and tribal politics have also spilled over into other sectors of American society, further exacerbating âvetocracyâ.

According to a Pew Research Center report in October 2021âbased on a survey of 17 advanced economies (including the US, Germany and the Republic of Korea), the USâis moreâpolitically divided than the otherâeconomies surveyed. Nineâinâten US respondents believe there are conflicts between people who support different political parties, and nearly 60% of Americans surveyedâthinkâtheirâfellow citizens no longer disagree simply over policies, but also over basic facts. â

Jungkun Seo, Professor of Political Scienceâat Kyung Hee University, observes that asâpolitical polarizationâintensifiesâin the US, the self-cleaning process of American democracy, whichâaims to driveâreform through elections, will no longerâbe able to functionâproperly. With theâSenate trappedâin aâfilibuster, the US Congress no longer serves as a representative body for addressing changesâin American society throughâlegislation.

(4) The flawed electoral rules impair fairness and justice

The US presidential election follows the time-honored Electoral College system, where the president and vice president are not elected directly by popular vote, but by the Electoral College consisting of 538âelectors. The candidate whoâachievesâa majority of 270 or more electoral votes wins the election.

The flaws of such an electoral system are self-evident. First, as the president-elect may notâbe theâwinner ofâthe national popular vote, there is a lack of broaderârepresentation. Second, as each state gets to decide its own electoral rules, this may create confusion and disorder. Third, the winner-takes-all system exacerbatesâinequality among states and betweenâpolitical parties. Itâleads to a huge waste of votes and discourages voter turnout. Voters in âdeep blueââand âdeep redââstates are oftenâneglected, while swing states becomeâdisproportionately moreâimportant where both parties seek to woo more supporters.

There have been five presidential electionsâin US history in which the winners of nationwideâpopular vote were not elected the president. The most recent case was the 2016âpresidential election in whichâRepublican candidate Donald Trump won 62.98 millionâpopular votes or 45.9% ofâthe total, while Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton wonâ65.85 million or 48% of popular votes. Although Trump lost the popular vote, he won 304 electoral votes while Clinton securedâonly 227, which gave Trumpâhis presidency.

Another flaw of the electoral system widely acknowledged by the US public is gerrymandering. In 1812, Governorâof Massachusetts Elbridge Gerry signed a bill in the interest of his own party, creating in hisâstate anâodd-shaped electoral districtâthat was compared to aâsalamander. Such practiceâwas later called gerrymandering, which refers to an unfair division ofâelectoral districtsâin favor ofâa particularâparty to win as many seats as possible and cement its advantage.

The USâconductsâa census every ten years. Following the completion of the census, redistricting or the redrawing of electoral district boundaries will take place underâthe principle of maintaining roughly equal population in every voting districtâwhile considering demographicâshifts. Under theâUS Constitution, eachâstate legislature has the power to redistrict. This leaves room for the majority party in state legislatures to manipulate the redrawing of electoral districts. Two principalâtactics areâoftenâused in gerrymandering. One is âpackingâ, i.e. concentrating the oppositionâpartyâs voters in a few districts, thus giving up these districts to secure the others. The other is âcrackingâ, i.e. splitting up areas where the oppositionâpartyâs supporters are concentrated and incorporating them into neighboring districts, thus diluting votes for the opposition party.

On 27 September 2021, the Democratic-governed state of Oregon became the first in the country to complete redistricting. Electoral districts firmly in the hands of the Democratic Party have increased from two to four, and swing districts reduced from two to one.âThis means that the Democratic Party can control 83% of the stateâs congressional districts with 57% of voters. On the contrary, the Republican-controlled state of Texas, with new electoral district boundaries determinedâon 25 October 2021, has seen districts held by Republicans grow from 22 to 24 and swing districts shrink from six to one. The Republican Party now occupiesâ65% of state House seats with just 52.1% of voters.

According to a YouGov poll in August 2021, just 16% of US adultâcitizensâsayâthey thinkâtheir statesââcongressional maps would be drawn fairly, while 44% sayâthey think the maps would be drawn unfairly and another 40% of adults sayâtheyâareâunsure if the maps will be fair. As US politics growsâmore polarized, bothâthe Republican and Democratic parties are seeking to maximize their own interests, and gerrymandering becomes the best approach.

Theâsuperdelegate system of the Democratic Party is also an impediment to fair election. The superdelegates include major Democratic leaders, members of the Democratic National Committee, Democratic members of Congress, and incumbent Democratic governors, and are seated automatically.âThe superdelegates may support any candidate they choose or follow the will of the Party leadershipâwithout giving any consideration to theâwishes of the general public.

The late political analyst Mark Plotkin wrote on The Hill that the âDemocratsââsuperdelegate system is unfair and undemocraticâ, and âthe process of eliminating this elitist exercise should immediately beginâ.

(5) Dysfunctionalâdemocracyâtriggersâtrust crisis

The American-styleâdemocracy isâmoreâlike a meticulously set up scene in Hollywood moviesâwhereâa bunch of well-heeled characters publicly pledge commitment to the people, but actually busy themselves with behind-the-scene deals. Political infighting, money politics, and vetocracy make it virtually impossible for quality governance to be delivered as desired by the general public. Americans are increasingly disillusioned with US politics and pessimistic about the American-styleâdemocracy.

A Gallup survey in October 2020 shows that only 19% of the Americans surveyed are âvery confidentâ about the presidential election, a record low since the survey was first conducted in 2004.

In November 2020, an online Wall Street Journal report argues that the 2020 general election can be seen as the culmination of a two-decade decline inâfaith in democracy in the US.

According to a poll by The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, only 16% of Americans say democracy is working well or extremely well; 45% think democracy isnât functioning properly, while another 38% say itâs working only somewhat well. A Pew Research Center survey finds that just 20% of Americans say they trust the federal government just about always or most of the time.

A Brookings online article in May 2021 indicates that the certification of the 2020 election results by all 50 states still leaves 77% of Republicanâvotersâquestioning the legitimacy of President Bidenâs election victory due to allegations of voter fraud. This is the first time such things happen since the 1930s.

A CNN poll in September reveals that 56% of Americans think democracy in the US is under attack; 52% reply they are just a little or not at all confident that elections reflect the will of the people; 51% say itâs likely that elected officials in the next few years will overturn the results of an election their party did not win.

A 2021 Pew survey conducted among 16,000 adults in 16 advanced economiesâand 2,500 adults in the US shows that 57% of international respondents and 72% of Americans believe that democracy in the US has not been a good example for others to follow in recent years.

2.Messy and chaotic practices of democracy

Thatâdemocracy in the US has gone wrong is reflectedânot only in its systemâdesignâandâgeneral structure, but also in the way it is put into practice. The USâis not a straight A student when it comes toâdemocracy, still less a role model for democracy. The gunshots and farce on Capitol Hill haveâcompletely revealed what is underneath theâgorgeous appearance of the American-styleâdemocracy. The death of Black American George Floyd has laid bare theâsystemic racism that exists in Americanâsociety for too long, and spurred a deluge of protests rippling throughout the country and even the whole world.

While the COVID-19 pandemic remains out of controlâin the US, the issue of mask-wearing and vaccination hasâtriggered furtherâsocial division and confrontation. Dividends of economic growthâare distributed unfairly, and income growth has stalled for mostâordinary peopleâforâa long period of time. The American-styleâdemocracyâcan hardlyâuphold public order and ethics, nor advanceâpublic well-beingâto the fullest.

(1) The Capitol riot that shocks the world

On the afternoon of 6 January 2021, thousands of Americansâgathered on Capitol Hill, Washington, D.C. and stormed the Capitol building in a bid to stopâthe joint session of the Congress fromâcertifyingâthe newly-elected president. The incident interrupted the transfer of US presidential power, leaving five dead and over 140 injured. It is the worst act of violenceâin Washington, D.C. since 1814 when the British troops set fire to the White House, and itâisâthe first time in more than 200 years that the Capitol was invaded. Senate Republican leader described it as a âfailed insurrectionâ. A scholar fromâthe US Council on Foreign Relations (CFR)âexclaims thatâthe US is not nearly as unique as many Americans believe, and that the Capitol riot should put an end to the notion of American exceptionalism, of an eternal shining city on a hill.

The assault on the Capitolâhas undermined the three major bedrocks ofâthe American-styleâdemocracy.

First, âdemocracyâ in the US is not democraticâas it claims. The refusal of some US politiciansâto recognize the election results andâtheir supportersâ subsequent violent storming of the Capitol building have severely undercut the credibility of democracy in the US.

Second, âfreedomâ in the USâis not free as it claims.âTwitter, Facebook and other social media platformsâsuspended theâpersonal accounts of some US politicians, a de facto announcement of their âdeath on social mediaâ. This hasâbust the myths of âfreedom of speechââin the US.

Third, the ârule of lawââin the US is notâbound by the law as it claims. The totally different attitudesâtaken by US law enforcement agencies toward the âBlack Lives Matterââ(BLM) protestsâand the Capitol riot are yet another reminder of the double standards in the US ârule of lawâ.

The assault on the Capitol sent shock waves throughoutâthe international community. While deploringâthe violence, many people also expressed disappointmentâat the US.

BritishâPrime Minister Boris Johnson tweeted that what happened in the US Capitol were âdisgraceful scenesâ.â

French President Emmanuel Macron said that âin one of the worldâs oldest democracies ... a universal ideaâââthat of âone person, one voteâââ is undermined.ââ

South African President Cyril Ramaphosa commentedâthat it âshook the foundationsââof democracy in the US.

Former Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono tweeted that the political farce in the US offers much food for thought, and that there is no perfect democracy, especially when it comes to its practices. â

(2) Entrenched racism

Racism is an indelible blotâon democracy in the US. While advocating âall men are created equalâ, the founding fathers of the US left the institution of slavery untouched in the Constitutionâof 1789. Today, although racial segregation has been ostensibly abolished in the US, white supremacy is still rife and rampant across the country. Discrimination against Black Americans and other racial minorities remains a systemic phenomenon.

American society has experienced relapses of its malaise of racial discrimination from time to time. On 25 May 2020, George Floyd, a BlackâAmerican, lost his life in Minnesota because of law enforcement violence by the police. âI canât breatheââââFloydâs desperate plea for life before his deathâââsparked public outrage. Afterwards, protests and demonstrations erupted in about 100 cities across the 50 states of America, demanding justice for Floyd and protesting against racial discrimination. The demonstrations continued more than 100 days after the incident.

What happened to George Floyd is merely an epitome of the tragic plight of Black Americans over the past centuries. Sandra Shullman, Past President ofâthe American Psychological Association,âsays thatâAmerica is in âa racism pandemicâ. The dream of civil rights leader Martin Luther King, Jr. remains unrealized.âAccording to an editorial ofâThe Indian Express, a mainstream newspaper of India, American racism has endured, subverting the countryâs deepest democratic institutions in the process.

In February 2021, Stanford News, a website of Stanford University,âcarriedâan article examining systemic racism in the US. The articleâsuggestsâthat in education, youth of color are more likely to be closely watched; in the criminal justice system, people of color, particularly Black men, are disproportionately targeted; and in the economy and employment, from who moves forward in the hiring process to who receives funding from venture capitalists, BlackâAmericans and other minority groups are discriminated against in the workplace and economy-at-large. A study by the University of Washington findsâthat around 30,800 people died from police violence between 1980 and 2018 in the US, which is about 17,100 higher than the official figure. It also indicatesâthat African Americans are 3.5 times more likely to be killed by police violence than white Americans.

The anger erupting across America is not just Black anger, but across racial lines. An article published on the website of The Jerusalem Postâof Israel notesâthat American Jews are concerned about right-wing antisemitism and violence driven by white supremacist groups. According to annual surveys conducted by the American Jewish Committee, in 2020, 43% US Jews feel less secure than a year ago, and in 2017, 41% say antisemitism is a serious problem in the US, up from 21% in 2016, 21% in 2015, and 14% in 2013.

The bullying ofâAmericans of Asian descentâis increasing in the US. Since the outbreak of COVID-19, there have been growingâcases of Asian Americans humiliated or attacked in public places. Statistics from the US Federal Bureau of Investigation indicateâthat hate crimes against people of Asian descent rose by 76%âin the USâin 2020. From March 2020 to June 2021, the organization Stop Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders Hate received over 9,000 incident reports.âA survey of young Asian Americansâonâthe National Broadcasting Companyâ(NBC)âwebsite showsâthat in the past year, a quarter of young Asian Americans became targets of racial bullying, nearly half of the respondents expressed pessimism about their situation, and a quarter of the respondents expressed fear about the situation of themselves and their families.

(3)âTragic mishandling of the COVID-19 pandemic

With the bestâhealth and medical resources in the worldâas it claims, the USâhas beenâa total mess when it comes to COVID response.âItâhas the worldâs highest numbersâof infections and deaths.

According to figures released byâJohns Hopkins University, as of the end ofâNovember 2021, confirmed COVID-19âcases in the US had exceeded 48âmillion, and the number of deaths had surpassedâ770,000,âboth the highestâin the world.

On 8 January this year, 300,777 new confirmed casesâwere reported, a record single-day increase sinceâtheâCOVID-19 outbreak in the US. On 13 Januaryâalone, 4,170 Americans died of COVID-19, far exceedingâtheâdeath toll of theâ9/11âterrorist attacks.

At the end of November, theâaverage daily increase of confirmedâcases in the US had climbedâto overâ70,000, and daily death tollâto over 700.

One in every 500 Americans have died of COVID-19. Up to now,âCOVID-19âdeathsâin the US haveâsurpassed its total death toll fromâthe 1919 Influenza Pandemic, and itsâcombined deaths in World War I, World War II, the Korean War, the Vietnam War, the Iraq War and the war in Afghanistan.

If the USâhad taken a science-based response, a lot more lives could have been saved. The pandemic, as epidemiologist and former head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention William Foege put it, isâaââslaughterâ.

The pandemic has taken a heavy toll on the USâeconomy. The rate and scale of business shutdown and unemployment in the country are beyond imagination, leaving a large number of Americans jobless. Peopleâsâanxiety and sense of powerlessness has been exacerbated by growing factors of social instability.

The COVID Hardship Watch released by the US Center on Budget and Policy Priorities on 29 July 2021 suggests that while there have been improvements over the situation in December 2020, hardship is widespread for Americans in the first half of 2021. Some 20 million adults live in households that have not got enough to eat, 11.40 million adult renters are behind on rent, facing the risk of being evicted.

As indicated in the statistics released byâthe US Census Bureau, by 5 July 2021, at least one member in 22% of all households with underage dependents had lost their source of income.

US consumer confidence has dropped substantially, and progress in job market recovery has stalled. Institutions such as Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Oxford Economics have significantly revised down growth forecasts for the US economy. At the same time, the pandemic, coupled withâthree rounds of massive economic stimulus plans, among other factors, has caused port congestion and supply shortages, pushing inflation higher.
